questions.question:
Question 1: In patients with confirmed sialolithiasis, what is the most common location of stone 
formation?
questions.explanation:
The most common site for salivary gland stone formation is the submandibular gland due to 
highly viscous secretions. 80% of submandibular stones are radio-opaque, while parotid duct stones are usually radiolucent 
and rarely visible on plain radiography. Parotid gland sialography is usually required to identify 
the stone. A stone located in the collecting duct or within the gland may be managed by either 
endoscopic retrieval or lithotripsy; in rare cases, surgical removal via a parotidectomy approach 
may be required. The below USG image shows a stone in the Wharton duct of the submandibular gland.

questions.question:
Question 2: Which of the following is true regarding management considerations in a patient with 
submandibular gland stones?

options.a: Surgical gland excision is the treatment of choice if patient is unresponsive to conservative
options.b: Associated chronic sialadenitis is a contraindication for sialendoscopy
options.c: Conventional radiography is mostly useless as more than 80% of submandibular stones are
options.d: Stones proximal to the lingual nerve can be removed via an intra-oral approach

questions.explanation:
If the stone is proximal to the lingual nerve, stone retrieval can be done via an intraoral surgical 
approach under general anesthesia. 80% of submandibular stones are radio-opaque. Conventional radiography is useful in the initial 
workup of salivary stones, but ultrasound, CT, MRI, and sialendoscopy are required for accurate 
diagnosis and localization (especially for smaller and parenchymal stones). The only contraindication for sialendoscopy is acute sialadenitis. This is because sialendoscopy 
and ductal dilation is more difficult in the setting of inflammation and there will be a greater 
likelihood of ductal trauma and potential spread of infection. Management of sialolithiasis should begin with conservative measures, oral hydration, analgesia, 
massaging of gland, sialogogues, and antibiotics (if there are signs of infection). If unsuccessful, 
the next step is based on the sialolith's size, number, and location: • Small stones (<4mm) - endoscopic removal using Dormia basket. 1039 
Sold by @itachibot • larger stones - external shockwave lithotripsy (ESWL) + fragment removal or Open surgery and 
stone removal • Surgical excision of the gland should always be a last resort If distal to lingual nerve: Make a longitudinal incision over the duct. Remove the stone. Suture the 
duct using absorbable suture. If proximal to lingual nerve: intraoral approach The image below shows a stone in the submandibular salivary duct.

questions.question:
Question 3: A 56-year-old man presented with complaints of recurrent bilateral painless swelling over the 
parotid glands. FNAC done showed acinar cell hypertrophy without any inflammatory signs. 
All of the following are associated with this condition except?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario and FNAC report of acinar hypertrophy are suggestive of sialadenosis. 
Hyperthyroidism is not associated with sialadenosis. Sialosis (sialadenosis) is defined as an asymptomatic, non-inflammatory, non-neoplastic 
parenchymal salivary gland disease. It is accompanied by a persistent painless bilateral swelling of 
the salivary glands, most commonly involving the parotid glands. Most cases of sialadenosis are 
observed in patients between 40 to 70 years of age, and the salivary gland swellings are often soft 
and symmetrical. On FNAC, acinar cell hypertrophy is seen without any inflammatory signs. Sialadenosis is associated with the following conditions: • Nutritional disorders • Bulimia nervosa • Vitamin deficiency • Endocrine disorders • Diabetes mellitus • Hypothyroidism 1040 
Sold by @itachibot • Metabolic disorders • Obesity • Cirrhosis • Malabsorption • Autoimmune disorders • Sjögren disease • Drug-induced • Valproic acid • Thiourea • Pregnancy • Alcoholism

questions.question:
Question 4: 1026 
Sold by @itachibot A 40-year-old man on routine dental checkup was found to have the following finding on 
orthopantomogram. What is the reason for the finding marked with the arrow?
questions.explanation:
The given orthopantomogram shows a right-sided clearly demarcated radiolucent lesion 
suggestive of a stafne bone cyst. It is the most common type of ectopic salivary tissue. It presents as an asymptomatic, clearly demarcated radiolucent lesion at the angle of the 
mandible, characteristically below the inferior dental neurovascular bundle. It is more common in 
males. Usually, no treatment is required. A dentigerous cyst is a cyst in relation to an unerupted tooth. Most commonly involves the 3rd 
molar. It is managed by enucleation and removal of the tooth.

questions.question:
Question 5: A 5 year-old-boy was brought to the OPD by his parents with a painless, soft, translucent 
swelling under the tongue. On examination, the swelling is as seen below. Which of the 
following statements best describe his condition? 1027 
Sold by @itachibot

options.a: Mucous retention cyst from a minor salivary gland
options.b: Mucous extravasation cyst from sublingual gland
options.c: Mucous extravasation cyst from a minor salivary gland
options.d: Mucous retention cyst from sublingual gland

questions.explanation:
The given scenario and image points to a diagnosis of an oral ranula. It is a mucous extravasation 
cyst arising from the sublingual gland. Ranula is a transilluminant mucocele. It is also known as "frog's belly", as it resembles the vocal 
sacs of a frog. It is of two types: • Oral ranula - It is a benign cystic lesion formed by extravasation of mucus, involving the 
sublingual gland. Clinically present as cystic swelling in the floor of the mouth. On examination 
fluctuation test and transillumination test is positive. It is conservatively managed 
by marsupialisation. Definitive management is excision of the cyst. Some may resolve 
spontaneously. • Cervical or plunging ranula- is a rare type of retention cyst arising from the sublingual gland. 
The mucous passes through the mylohyoid muscle diaphragm to enter the neck. Clinically present 
as intraoral and cervical swelling. Diagnosis is made by USG or MRI. Management includes 
excision of sublingual gland + aspiration of saliva out of the sac. 1041 
Sold by @itachibot Note: Oral ranulas located in the floor of the mouth can often be confused with an epidermoid 
cyst.

questions.question: Question 6: Which of the following is true regarding salivary gland tumors?

options.a: 90% of the minor salivary gland tumors are malignant
options.b: The submandibular gland is the most common site for salivary tumors
options.c: Adenoid cystic carcinoma is the most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland
options.d: A salivary gland tumor with perineural invasion is mucoepidermoid carcinoma

questions.explanation:
90% of the minor salivary gland tumors are malignant, and the common sites are the upper lip, 
palate, and retromolar regions. Option B: The most common site for salivary tumors is the parotid gland, mostly involving the 
superficial lobe. Option C: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma is the most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland. Option D: Adenoid cystic carcinoma is known to be associated with perineural invasion.

questions.question:
Question 7: A man presents with a slowly progressive swelling over the past 1 and 1/2 years. On 
examination, it has a variable consistency and appears as shown in the image. What is the 
probable cause? 1028 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
A slowly progressive swelling, with a variable consistency, lifting the ear lobe, is suggestive of 
pleomorphic adenoma of the parotid gland. Pleomorphic adenoma, the most common benign salivary gland tumor, primarily affects the 
parotid gland, particularly its superficial lobe. It is also referred to as a mixed tumor due to its 
combination of epithelial and mesenchymal components. This tumor most commonly occurs in 
females around the age of 40. Clinical features: • Painless, slow-growing swelling • Lobulated, firm, variable in consistency • Lifts the earlobe • No facial nerve involvement • Curtain sign positive - cannot be moved above the zygomatic bone. • In case of deep lobe involvement, tonsils, and faucial pillars will be pushed medially. • Features of malignancy - a sudden increase in size, ulceration of the overlying skin, facial nerve 
palsy (involvement of facial nerve), painful swelling, and restriction of jaw movements. Fine needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) is the investigation of choice in diagnosing pleomorphic 
adenoma. Open biopsy is contraindicated due to the chances of injury to the facial nerve. All tumors of the superficial lobe of the parotid gland should be managed by superficial 
parotidectomy. Radical parotidectomy is performed for malignant pleomorphic adenoma. Other options: Option A: Adamantinoma is a low-grade malignant tumor that usually presents with pre-tibial 
pain and swelling since it most commonly affects the tibial diaphysis. Option B: Dermoid cysts present as firm painless subcutaneous nodules and are of 4 types: 1042 
Sold by @itachibot • Sequestration dermoid - sequestration of epithelium during embryological development. • Tubulodermoid - accumulation of secretions from ectodermal tube/duct • Implantation dermoid - implantation of the epidermis due to trauma • Teratomatous dermoid - having all 3 germ layers (ecto, meso, and endoderm) Option D: Sebaceous cysts are retention cysts of the sebaceous glands that present as smooth, 
non-tender, non-transillumination swelling with a punctum (in 70% of the patients).

questions.question:
Question 8: A 45-year-old woman presented with painless swelling in front of the left ear for the past 2 
years. On examination, her left earlobe was lifted and the curtain sign was positive. Which of 
the following is false about the condition?

options.a: Treatment of choice is total radical parotidectomy
options.d: Malignant form shows LMN facial palsy

questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of pleomorphic adenoma. The treatment of choice is 
superficial parotidectomy. Clinical features: • Painless, slow-growing swelling • Lobulated, firm, elastic-to-hard in consistency • Lift the ear lobe • Free from deeper structures • With no facial nerve involvement • Curtain sign positive - cannot be moved above the zygomatic bone Pleomorphic adenoma involves the superficial lobe of parotid gland and should be managed by 
superficial parotidectomy. Types of Parotidectomy • If only the superficial lobe is involved: • Superficial parotidectomy - only superficial lobe removed. Usually done in benign conditions. • If both lobes are involved: • Total conservative parotidectomy - both lobes are removed but the facial nerve is preserved. • Total radical parotidectomy - both lobes and facial nerve removed. Sometimes it may undergo malignant transformation. The malignant form is mixed malignant 
tumor or carcinoma ex pleomorphic adenoma (most aggressive salivary malignancy). Signs of malignant transformation • A rapid increase in size • Pain and ulceration • Facial nerve involvement (LMN) • Lymph node involvement • Restricted jaw movements 1043 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 9: Technetium-99m pertechnetate scintigraphy done for a patient with a chronic painless facial 
swelling is shown below. Which of the following statements is false regarding this tumor? 1029 
Sold by @itachibot

options.a: This tumor has no malignant potential
options.b: Superficial parotidectomy is the treatment of choice
options.c: Histology shows a double layer of epithelial cells with dense lymphoid stroma
options.d: It is the most common unilateral benign tumor of the parotid gland

questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario and image are suggestive of Warthin’s tumor. These tumors appear as 
hot spots on radionuclide scans because of the high mitochondrial content in oncocytes that 
incorporate technetium-99m. The most common benign tumor of the parotid gland is 
pleomorphic adenoma. Warthin’s tumor or papillary cystadenoma lymphomatosum usually presents as a unilateral 
tumor. It is usually seen in the lower poles of the parotid and is commonly associated with 
smoking. It occurs most often in elderly males. It has no malignant potential. Histology shows tumor cells lined by a double layer of neoplastic epithelial cells resting on the 
dense lymphoid stroma. FNAC is the preferred investigation. Superficial parotidectomy is the 
treatment of choice. Note: Both pleomorphic adenoma and Warthin's tumors commonly present as unilateral tumors. 
A bilateral presentation is usually rare. However in rare cases, if there is a bilateral benign salivary 
tumor, the tumor is most likely to be a Warthin's tumor.

questions.question: Question 10: Match the following
questions.explanation:
Godwin’s tumor • Benign lymphoepithelial tumor of the salivary gland. • It is associated with CMV. • < 5% shows malignancy - known as Eskimoma. Kuttner’s tumor is chronic sclerosing sialadenitis of the submandibular gland. Oncocytoma (oxyphil adenoma) - • Usually benign, originating from oncocytes. 1044 
Sold by @itachibot • Grossly - tan-colored small, well-circumscribed, and encapsulated. • Microscopically - large oncocytes with swollen granular cytoplasm. • Appear as a hotspot on Technetium-99m pertechnetate scintigraphy due to an abundance of 
mitochondria. Tumor

questions.question:
Question 11: An elderly woman presents with recent onset facial asymmetry and a lump over the roof of 
the mouth for the past 1 year. On examination, a solitary erythematous swelling with diffuse 
borders is seen over the left hard palate. Biopsy of the lesion reveals a swiss cheese pattern. 
Which of the following conditions is she likely to have?
questions.explanation:
The given scenario and biopsy finding is suggestive of adenoid cystic carcinoma. Facial 
asymmetry points to the perineural invasion of the tumor into the facial nerve, which is 
characteristic of adenoid cystic carcinoma. It is the second most common malignant tumor of the parotid gland. It is a slow-growing tumor 
most commonly involving the parotid and submandibular glands. Histology shows a swiss cheese 
pattern. The tubular type has the best prognosis, while the solid type has the worst. It has a deceptively benign histologic appearance characterized by indolent, locally invasive 
growth with a high propensity for local recurrence and distant metastasis. The most common site 
of distant metastasis is the lung. Treatment involves removal of the gross tumor, with radiation 
therapy for the microscopic disease.

questions.question:
Question 13: As a 1st year resident assisting in a superficial parotidectomy, you have been asked to identify 
the facial nerve trunk. All of the following structures can be used for its localization except:
questions.explanation:
The inferior belly of the omohyoid muscle is not used as an anatomical landmark for the 
identification of the facial nerve trunk. There are two methods for localization of the facial nerve trunk: 1. Anterograde method: In this method, the facial nerve trunk is identified based on the 
anatomical landmarks after it exits from the stylomastoid foramen. The anatomical landmarks 
include: • Conley's pointer is the inferior portion of the cartilaginous canal. The facial nerve trunk lies 1 cm 
deep and inferior to its tip. • Posterior belly of digastric- The facial nerve lies superior to the upper border of the muscle. • Mastoid process- Upon drilling it, the nerve is identified proximally. • Squamotympanic fissure is a fissure in the temporal bone, which runs from TMJ to the tympanic 
cavity. The facial nerve runs through this fissure. • Styloid process- The facial nerve lies superficial to it. 2. Retrograde method: In this method, the main branches of the facial nerve trunk are identified 
and are then traced proximally until the main tunk is identified. Some of the main branches that 
are commonly used for tracing the facial nerve trunk include: • Buccal branch lies in relation to the parotid gland • Marginal mandibular branch lies in relation to the facial vessels • Temporal branch The given image points to the facial nerve (marked by arrow). 1046 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 14: A patient is scheduled to undergo a total parotidectomy with selective node dissection of 
levels Ib, IIa, IIb, and III. Which of the following groups of lymph nodes will be removed 
during the procedure?
questions.explanation:
Among the given options, only submandibular (Level Ib) and middle jugular nodes (Level III) 
nodes will be removed. The other nodes that will be removed in the procedure will be upper 
jugular nodes (Level IIa and IIb). Selective neck dissection has been used in the treatment of patients with cancer of the upper 
aerodigestive tract (oral cavity, pharynx, larynx), cancer of the thyroid gland, cutaneous 
malignancies, and cancer of the salivary gland. The type of selective neck dissection used varies 
depending on the lymphatic drainage and metastatic pattern associated with the primary 
cancer site.

questions.question:
Question 15: A patient with pleomorphic adenoma is posted for submandibular gland excision. Which of 
the following nerves is least likely to be injured during this procedure?

options.a: Marginal mandibular branch of the facial nerve

questions.explanation:
The inferior alveolar nerve is the nerve least likely to be affected by submandibular surgery. Nerves at risk for injury during removal of the submandibular gland include: • Marginal mandibular branch of the facial nerve • Lingual nerve • Hypoglossal nerve An important landmark in submandibular gland dissection is the posterior border of the 
mylohyoid muscle. Once identified, it can be retracted to reveal the deep lobe of the gland. The 
hypoglossal nerves lie deep to the submandibular capsule and should not be damaged during 
intracapsular dissection. The facial artery is ligated twice during the surgery. 1047 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 16: Which nerve is involved in Frey’s syndrome?
questions.explanation:
The auriculotemporal nerve (V3 nerve) is involved in Frey's syndrome (gustatory sweating). Frey’s syndrome is also known as Dupuy syndrome or auriculotemporal syndrome. It commonly 
develops after parotid surgery. It is caused by an aberrant regeneration of post-ganglionic 
parasympathetic nerve fibers crossed along the sympathetic pathways to the sweat glands near the 
parotid region. Clinical features are due to the result of salivary stimulation (by the smell or taste of food) leading 
to the sweating and flushing of the periauricular region on the involved side of the face. A starch 
iodine test is used for diagnosis. Treatment ranges from antiperspirants (in mild cases) to tympanic neurectomy or botulinum 
toxin injection (in severe cases). It can be prevented by incorporating careful extracapsular 
dissection and closure of the superficial musculoaponeurotic layer during parotidectomy. 1048 
Sold by @itachibot Other options: Option A: Facial nerve is the 7th cranial nerve that supplies the muscles of the face, and results in 
facial paralysis if injured during parotidectomy Option B: Oculomotor is the 3rd cranial nerve which supplies the extraocular muscles. If injured 
during ophthalmic surgeries, it results in ocular paralysis and the eye pointing down and out. Option D: Glossopharyngeal nerve is the 9th cranial nerve and its injury causes loss of taste 
sensation from the posterior 1/3rd of the tongue.

questions.question:
Question 17: After parotidectomy patients complains of loss of sensation while shaving. Which nerve is 
most likely affected?
questions.explanation:
After parotid surgery, the nerve involved in the loss of sensation while shaving is the great 
auricular nerve. The great auricular nerve (GAN) originates from the second and third nerve roots of the cervical 
plexus (C2-C3). It supplies the skin over the lower pinna, pre-auricular region, and angle of the 
mandible (image below). The main trunk passes over the sternocleidomastoid and into the 
anterosuperior portion of the parotid glands and branches into the anterior and posterior GAN. 
The anterior branch of GAN is often injured during parotid surgery during the initial elevation of 
the skin flap. When GAN is injured, it can cause reduced sensations in the earlobe, pre-auricular skin, and the 
angle of the mandible that can interfere with habits such as shaving, wearing earrings, etc. 1049 
Sold by @itachibot Other options: Option A: The auriculotemporal nerve, a branch of the mandibular nerve (V3 of trigeminal) 
supplies the posterior part of the temple, tragus, and adjoining auricle. It does not supply the area 
where a person is likely to shave. However, the injury to the auriculotemporal nerve resulting in 
aberrant regeneration would result in Frey's Syndrome (gustatory sweating). Option C: Though the facial nerve is the most common nerve affected during parotidectomy, any 
damage would result in facial paralysis and not loss of sensation of the face. Option D: The mandibular nerve is a branch of the trigeminal nerve (cranial nerve V) that supplies 
the skin over the mandible, lower lip, and cheek. However, they are not injured during 
parotidectomy.

questions.question:
Question 18: At what age should the congenital defect (shown in the image below) be ideally repaired? 1032 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given image shows a unilateral cleft lip. Repair of cleft lip (primary palate) along with 
associated nasal deformities is done at 3–6 months of age.

questions.question:
Question 19: A child with a cleft lip is posted for surgery. Which of the following methods is not used to 
repair this condition?
questions.explanation:
Wardill’s method is not a method of cleft lip repair. It is a technique for hard palate closure. Cleft-lip repair techniques: • Millard’s rotation advancement technique (most common) • Thompson • Le Mesurier • Tennison–Randall 1050 
Sold by @itachibot Techniques of hard palate closure include the use of the following: • Unipedicled hard palate mucoperiosteal flaps as in the Wardill-Veau-Kilner repair • Bipedicled hard palate mucoperiosteal flaps as in the von Langenbeck repair

questions.question:
Question 20: Which among the following is an oral cavity lesion with a high-risk of malignant 
transformation?
questions.explanation:
Speckled erythroplakia has a high risk of malignant transformation. Malignancy risk: High-risk lesions Erythroplakia (homogenous/speckled) • Seen as red velvety lesions • Speckled type is the most aggressive • The treatment of choice is surgical ablation Proliferative verrucous leucoplakia • A white patchy lesion that cannot be rubbed off. • Speckled leucoplakia has an erythematous base • The treatment of choice is excision Chronic hyperplastic candidiasis • White patches that can be rubbed off with a hyperaemic border. • Management includes prolonged treatment with topical antifungals or systemic antifungal 
therapy. If no improvement or if there are any signs of dysplasia, surgical excision is done. Medium risk lesions Oral submucous fibrosis • Hypersensitive reaction to betel nut product. • Other risk factors are - tobacco, chili, vitamin deficiency • Clinical features - trismus, ankyloglossia, soreness, and burning sensation in the mouth. • Management includes antioxidants, intralesional triamcinolone, and surgical excision. Syphilitic glossitis • Associated with tertiary syphilis Low-risk lesions Oral lichen planus • Reticulate fine lace-like pattern. • Management is topical corticosteroids. Discoid lupus erythematosus 1051 
Sold by @itachibot Discoid keratosis congenita Speckled erythroplakia:

questions.question:
Question 21: A 35-year-old man presented with complaints of difficulty in opening his mouth, restricted 
tongue movements, and a burning sensation in the mouth while eating food. He is a smoker 
and chews pan masala. On examination, scarring is present in the oral cavity. What is the 
most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The most likely diagnosis is oral submucous fibrosis. It is a premalignant lesion of the oral cavity, 
in which fibrous bands are formed beneath the oral mucosa. Risk factors are • Betel nut • Chilli • Tobacco • Vitamin deficiency Clinical features include ankyloglossia, trismus, soreness, and a burning sensation in the mouth 
while eating. Management includes intralesional steroids, vitamin supplements, and surgical excision. Option A: Plummer-Vinson syndrome is characterized by post cricoid web that is associated with 
iron deficiency anemia, glossitis, and koilonychia. It usually presents as dysphagia. Option B: Proliferative verrucous leucoplakia appears as a white patchy lesion, that cannot be 
rubbed off. Option D: Erythroplakia is seen as bright red velvety plaque in the oral cavity.

questions.question:
Question 22: A 57-year-old male patient presents to the surgery OPD, with a 7cm lesion over the left buccal 
mucosa and difficulty opening the mouth. On examination, the right cervical lymph node is 
4cm in size with overlying skin involvement. What is the TNM staging of this lesion?
questions.explanation:
1052 
Sold by @itachibot The TNM staging in this patient is T4bN3bMX. A 7-cm primary tumor in the oral cavity with 
difficulty in opening mouth denotes a locally advanced tumor: T4b. Contralateral cervical lymph 
node involvement with skin involvement (extranodal extension-positive): N3b Note: Here the skin invasion corresponds to ENE positive, and hence, the N staging is N3b 
instead of N2c (contralateral lymph nodes, <6 cm and ENE■negative).

questions.question:
Question 23: Identify the given incision used for maxillectomy. 1034 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The image shows Weber–Ferguson incision which is used to access the floor of the maxillary sinus 
in the case of maxillary carcinoma. The rest of the options are incisions used for modified radical neck dissection (MRND).

questions.question: Question 24: What is this approach used in the treatment of oral cancer?
questions.explanation:
The given image shows the visor approach. In the visor approach, an incision is made extending from one end of the mandible to the opposite 
side and subplatysmal flaps are elevated superiorly over the mandible (like a visor of a helmet). 
This approach provides a wide exposure to remove larger lesions involving the anterior oral 
cavity that is not amenable to a peroral approach. This avoids a lip-splitting incision but has the 
disadvantage of anesthesia of chin/lower lip (due to the sacrifice of submental nerves). The surgical approach selected for excision of oral cavity tumors depends on the size of the tumor, 
location (anterior vs posterior), proximity to bone (mandible or maxilla), and the need to perform 
neck dissection. The most commonly employed approaches are as follows: • Peroral - accessible early-stage tumors • Lower cheek flap - tumors requiring partial 
mandibulectomy or large posterolateral tumors that cannot be accessed via a peroral approach 1053 
Sold by @itachibot • Upper cheek flap - tumors requiring partial maxillectomy or those involving the hard palate, 
upper gum, upper gingivobuccal sulcus and anterior soft palate • Mandibulotomy - 
larger tumors of the posterior oral cavity, tumors that involve the base of the tongue 
or pharyngeal wall. • Visor flap - larger lesions of the anterior oral cavity involving the anterior floor of the mouth and lower gum that are not amenable to a peroral approach Commando operation is the combined mandibular resection and neck node dissection. It is used 
mainly for carcinoma of the tongue.

questions.question:
Question 25: You will use an Abbe-Estlander flap for the reconstruction of which of the following 
structures?
questions.explanation:
Abbé- Estlander flaps are used for the reconstruction of the lip. They are lip switch flaps based on the sublabial or superior labial artery. When the defect involves 
the commissure, the Estlander flap is used, and the Abbé flap is used for more midline defects.

questions.question:
Question 26: A woman from Himachal Pradesh, presented with complaints of neck swelling for the past 1 
year. On examination, a firm, non-tender, pulsatile mass was palpated on the left side of the 
neck. The mass is mobile from side to side, but not up and down. A carotid angiogram of the 
patient is shown below. Which of the following is false regarding this condition?

options.b: Shamblin classification is used for staging
options.d: FNAC is the initial investigation of choice

questions.explanation:
The given scenario and carotid angiogram showing splaying of the bifurcation of the carotids, also 
known as lyre sign points to a diagnosis of chemodectoma. Fine-needle aspiration cytology 
(FNAC) is contraindicated when a chemodectoma is suspected. Chemodectoma is also known as carotid body tumor (aka potato tumor). It is a benign tumor of 
the neuroendocrine tissue of the carotid body. It has a higher incidence at high altitudes because 
of chronic hypoxia, which leads to carotid body hyperplasia. The tumor presents as a slowly enlarging mass that is firm, rubbery, pulsatile, mobile from side to 
side but not up and down. A bruit may be heard. Family history can be present in 10% of the 1054 
Sold by @itachibot cases. Shamblin classification is used for staging carotid body tumors.

questions.question:
Question 27: The most common site of branchial cyst is  
.

options.a: Junction of upper and middle third of the sternomastoid muscle
options.b: Junction of middle and lower third of the sternomastoid muscle
options.d: Between the two heads of the sternomastoid muscle

questions.explanation:
The most common site of a branchial cyst is at the junction of the upper and middle third of the 
sternomastoid muscle at its anterior border. The below image shows a large right-sided branchial cyst. Branchial cyst develops due to the persistence of the cervical sinus. The cervical sinus is formed 
when the 2nd arch mesoderm overgrows the succeeding arches and overhangs them as shown in 
the image. The space between the overhanging 2nd pharyngeal arch and the 3rd, 4th, and 6th 
arches is called the cervical sinus. The cavity of the cervical sinus is lined by ectoderm and 1055 
Sold by @itachibot normally gets obliterated. Branchial cysts are usually lined by squamous epithelium and contain thick, turbid fluid full of 
cholesterol crystals. It is fluctuant and may transilluminate when it contains clear fluid. A branchial fistula may be acquired or congenital. The congenital fistula is seen at the junction of 
the middle and lower third of the sternomastoid (option B). An acquired fistula is usually seen in 
cases of incomplete surgery for the branchial cyst or spontaneous rupture, and it is seen at the 
same site as the cyst.

questions.question:
Question 28: To which group of lymph nodes does a tumor limited to the glottis of the larynx spread 
commonly?
questions.explanation:
Tumors limited to the glottis usually do not spread to any lymph nodes, as there are no 
lymphatics in the vocal cords. However, if the tumor invades the supra- or the infra-glottic spaces, 
lymph node spread can occur. The most common malignant tumor of the larynx is squamous cell carcinoma. Glottis is the most 
common site of laryngeal cancer.

questions.question: Question 29: Radical neck dissection spares which of the following structures?
questions.explanation:
Digastric muscle is spared in radical neck dissection (RND). RND is used in the treatment of 
malignant lesions of the neck with local spread or metastasis. In 1905, Crile described RND where Level I-V LN, sternocleidomastoid (SCM), internal jugular 
vein (IJV), and XI cranial nerve (spinal accessory nerve) are removed. In 1962, Suarez described modified RND (MRND) where Level I-V LNs are removed and the 
following are preserved: • MRND I - XI cranial nerve 1056
